head.title: Long Bond's Yield 5.72%, a New Low

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: Long Bond's Yield 5.72%, a New Low

abstract.p: Bond prices end higher for fourth straight session, pushing yields further into record-low territory; Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond closes up 9/32, to price of 105 25/32, while yield falls to 5.72 percent, beating record low of 5.74 percent set on Jan 5; graphs (M)

block.p: Bond prices ended higher for the fourth straight session yesterday, pushing yields further into record-low territory and inducing more corporate borrowers to sell debt.

Although the appetite for bonds was not as hearty as on Monday, investors were still motivated to buy on resilient speculation that the Federal Reserve's next adjustment of interest-rate policy might be down. Lower rates tend to enhance the value of bonds already in circulation.
Bond prices ended higher for the fourth straight session yesterday, pushing yields further into record-low territory and inducing more corporate borrowers to sell debt.

Although the appetite for bonds was not as hearty as on Monday, investors were still motivated to buy on resilient speculation that the Federal Reserve's next adjustment of interest-rate policy might be down. Lower rates tend to enhance the value of bonds already in circulation.

The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond closed up 9/32, to a price of 105 25/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.72 percent, beating the record low of 5.74 percent set on Monday.

Long-term prices initially fell but rallied in the late afternoon after corporate debt sales were met with good demand, a sign that the broader pressures pushing up bond prices have not peaked. Securities dealers who had sold long-term Treasuries ahead of the uncertainty over those corporate sales bought them back.

''The initial selling came from large hedge funds,'' said Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. He also attributed some of the early selling to dealers who were taking profits from the recent rally on ''perhaps a feeling that the bond market had overshot reality.''

Among the $2 billion of corporate debt priced was International Business Machines' $700 million of 30-year debentures through Merrill Lynch, yielding 6.5 percent, about 79 basis points above the Government's long bond. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Following are results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new 52-week bills:

Average Price . . . 94.879 Discounted Rate . . . 5.06% Coupon Yield . . . 5.34% High Price . . . 94.889 Discounted Rate . . . 5.06% Coupon Yield . . . 5.34% Low Price . . . 94.879 Discounted Rate . . . 5.05% Coupon Yield . . . 5.33% Accepted at low price . . . 51% Total applied for . . . $48,355,101 Accepted . . . $17,813,541 Noncompetitive . . . $1,058,116
